STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 3, 2025
Dr. Robert Powell
Family Service & Children’s Aid- Jackson County
330 W. Michigan Ave.,
Jackson, MI, 49201-2121
RE: License#: CB380201116
Dear Dr. Powell:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 5/28/25. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following: (c) A physical examination for
each child as follows, unless a greater frequency is
medically indicated:
(i) A comprehensive medical examination, including a
behavioral/mental health and trauma screening, within
30 calendar days from the date the child entered into
an out-of-home placement, regardless of the date of
the last physical examination.
One of six foster care files did not have a well child exam completed within 30
days of the youth re-entering care. The previous medical exam was in 2022.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(c) Available known information about the child's
health.
One of six foster care files did not document the required information at
placement.

CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
One of six foster care files did not document the required information at
placement.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
One of six foster care files did not document the required information at
placement.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
One of six foster care files did not document the required information at
placement.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
One of six foster care files did not document the required information at
placement.

CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster
parents to understand the plan for the child and the
parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a
copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan
with the parent or parents and foster parents. The
agency must inform the parent or parents and foster
parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the
child and the child's family is confidential.
Two of six case files did not document the plan was reviewed with or provided to
a parent and foster parent.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Licensing recommendation- The agency was reminded to include SOGIE
recommendations in sections 15 & 16 of the licensing report for foster homes.
• Initial Placement Outline- The agency was provided with clarification about
who is responsible for completing an initial placement outline. If DHHS places
the youth in their home, then loans the home and gives the case to the
agency, DHHS is responsible for the placement outline. If the agency
provides placement and accepts the case, the agency is responsible for
completing the placement outline. If the agency agrees to accept the case
and DHHS physically places the child in the agency's foster home, the agency
must ensure a placement outline is completed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Education information- The agency was advised to update the education tab
for youth for the 2024-2025 school year.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
6/26/24 interim review resulted in a CAP, approved 7/12/24. During the 2025
renewal review, there were no repeat violations. The agency reported CAP
implementation was successful over the past year. Agency staff continue to review
the CAP and follow action steps to maintain compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The 5/22/2025 Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed and discussed. The
Chief Administrator reported the agency has followed the 2024 CAP and maintains
substantial compliance with licensing rules. The Chief Administrator indicated the
CAP had a positive impact on helping supervisors and managers track compliance
and implement new procedures that were necessary. The Chief Administrator
identified some difficulties over the report period with staff changes, including the
long time Program Manager. However, the agency pulled together to implement
some strategies to adjust and manage the new workload in a balanced way. While
it was challenging at first, they report the agency is now running smoothly and
communication among staff continues to work in a beneficial way.
The Chief Administrator reported only one unplanned placement disruption during
this review period. This was due to extreme emotional abuse of a foster child in a
borrowed home situation. After an investigation determined findings by MDHHS,
the child was moved to a relative’s home.
Financial Overview
The agency's 2024 financial assessment and 2025 budget were reviewed. No
financial concerns were noted.
Staff Interviews
Three staff were interviewed on-site. One staff was with the agency for less than a
year; two staff were there over a year. All three staff reported there were some
changes and challenges over the past year, including the Program Manager
leaving the agency. However, all three staff reported that everyone worked
together to make sure things went smoothly. Staff reported they all count on one
another for support and could not do this job without each other. Staff stated their
supervisors are incredibly supportive and knowledgeable. Staff enjoy the
collaborative process with their clinical department and the little things the agency
does to recognize their work. There were no concerns or areas of improvement
identified.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency remains in the same location as previous years. The building is
located in downtown Jackson, with many other businesses. The agency operates

their program out of two buildings, located on the same block. The building has
sufficient space for staff to work and meet, proper space for clients to visit, and
secure storage for confidential documents.
VII. AGENCY ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
_ ____________May 30, 2025________________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 3, 2025

Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
